\clearpage
\section{Advanced port usage}
\label{summary:documentation}\label{summary::doc}\label{summary:advanced-port-usage}

When running out of 1-bit ports, it may be possible to use a 4-bit port
instead to emulate four 1-bit ports, or to use a 32-bit port to emulate 32
1-bit ports.


\subsection{module\_zip}
\label{summary:module-zip}

This module can ZIP and UNZIP data onto 4-bit ports:

\begin{tabular}{llll}
\Toprule
Functionality provided & \multicolumn{2}{>{\setlength{\hsize}{2\hsize}\addtolength{\hsize}{2\tabcolsep}}l}{Resources required} & Status\\
 & 4-bit port &  & Memory\\
quad zip and out & 1 & 1250 bytes & Implemented\\
quad zip and in & 1 & 600 bytes & Implemented\\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}



\clearpage
\section{Zipping and Unzipping data onto ports}
\label{api-zip:zipping-and-unzipping-data-onto-ports}\label{api-zip::doc}

The zip module can input words from a 4-bit port, and output words to a
4-bit port as if these were four 1-bit ports.


\subsection{API}
\label{api-zip:api}\index{outputWordsZipped (C function)}

\texttt{\phantomsection\label{api-zip:outputWordsZipped}void outputWordsZipped(buffered out port:32 p, int b0, int b1, int b2, int b3)}

\vspace{-2mm}
\sloppy
\begin{indentation*}{\blockindentlen}{0mm}

Function that outputs 4 words to a single 4-bit buffered port.


Each word is output to one of the 4 bits serialised.


\begin{option}

\item[Parameters]\begin{itemize}
\item   \textbf{p} -- port to output to

\item   \textbf{b0} -- word to output to bit 0 of port p

\item   \textbf{b1} -- word to output to bit 1 of port p

\item   \textbf{b2} -- word to output to bit 2 of port p

\item   \textbf{b3} -- word to output to bit 3 of port p

\end{itemize}


\end{option}
\vspace{-3mm}


\end{indentation*}
\fussy
\index{inputWordsZipped (C function)}

\texttt{\phantomsection\label{api-zip:inputWordsZipped}\{int,int,int,int\} i inputWordsZipped(buffered in port:32 p)}

\vspace{-2mm}
\sloppy
\begin{indentation*}{\blockindentlen}{0mm}

Function that inputs 4 words from a single 4-bit buffered port.


Each word is input from one of the 4 bits serialised.


\begin{option}

\item[Parameters]\begin{itemize}
\item   \textbf{p} -- port to input from

\end{itemize}


\item[Returns]the four words, the first word is bit 0, the 4th return value is bit 3

\end{option}
\vspace{-3mm}


\end{indentation*}
\fussy

declared as buffered ports:

the source code of the two functions.
\end{fullwidth}%
